text: so debugging distributed systems is
something that's really challenging
which a lot of the previous talks have
focused on so one of the reasons for
this challenge is knowing where the
problem is in our distributed system it
could be in any one of the many
components that comprise the distributed
system it could be in one of the several
stack layers like that the components

kernel or the network layer it could
also be a result of emergent behavior
that only happens when you put all of
your system together so today people use
instrumentation and also boating methods
to debug distributed systems they
basically add instrumentation points to
different components and one problem
with this is that different problems
benefit from different instrumentation
points and if you want to instrument
everything and add instrumentation
points for every problem that may have
have happen in the fiercest 'im then
basically you will be drowning an
instrumentation data and your system
would be collecting more instrumentation
data rather than doing useful work so
and today's debugging happens in air
cycle basically we first gathered data
from current instrumentation and then we
try to find a problem using this
instrumentation if we can't we add more
instrumentation and then we collect more
data onto and we continue with the cycle
until we can localize the performance
enough to find come up with a solution
